newsitem.title: INDIA: India concerned over oil after attack on Iraq.
newsitem.headline: India concerned over oil after attack on Iraq.

text.p: Indian Finance Minister P. Chidambaram said on Friday India was concerned over the impact this week's U.S. missile attacks on Iraq could have on its oil import bill and economy.
"Look at what happened over the last two or three days," he told parliament, replying to a debate on the federal budget for 1996/97 (April-March).
"What happens to our oil import bill? What happens to our foreign exchange reserves?" he asked.
India imports about 40 percent of its oil and product needs, accounting for some $6.5 billion in 1995/96 ended last March -- or 20 percent of its total imports that year.

U.S. forces fired a total of 44 cruise missiles at air defence targets in southern Iraq on Tuesday and Wednesday. The attacks were prompted by the Iraqi army's incursion into Kurdish areas in northern Iraq last Saturday.
"It is a matter of some concern to me that import growth has slowed down in the past four months but oil imports have grown by 40 percent," Chidambaram said. He gave no details.
Chidambaram said crude prices this year had risen to $21 a barrel from $16.5 per barrel to $21. "The external economy has its impact on the Indian economy," he added."
He said India must try to resolve a shortage of products by investing more in the oil sector.
"The answer lies in increasing investments in the petroleum sector, exploring new oil reserves and finding new oil reserves," he said.
